artist: engraver: Jacques de Gheyn II; designer: after Dirck Barendsz.; publisher: Joos de Bosscher
description: black and white print of a fountain in natural landscape; several nude women bathing in a fountain at L; Actaeon at C, walking towards the L, with head and feet of a stag and arms of a man; he is holding a spear in one hand and leashes for two hounds in the other; hinged at top to cardstock mat
inscription:
Recto, l.l., in the plate: Jacobus de gheyn Sculptor
Recto, l.l., in the plate: Boscher excu.
Recto, l.l., in the plate:Theodorus Bernardus invt.
Verso, l.l. in pen and brown ink: N:H
signed: BL, within plate: Iacobus de gheyn sculptor / Theodorus Barnardus inut. / Boscher excu.
text:
Publius Ovidius Naso (43 BCE-c. 17 CE), commonly known as Ovid, was a Roman poet. His colorful mythological narrative, Metamorphoses, became a primary source for Renaissance and later artists looking for dramatic subjects from antiquity. In the stories, human beings morph into plants, rocks, constellations, and—as in the story of Diana and Actaeon—animals.

Ovid describes how Diana, the goddess of the hunt, bathed in a forest lake along with her companion nymphs. While out hunting, Actaeon came upon the lake and saw the naked women. As punishment for his intrusion, the goddess turned Actaeon into a stag. This engraving shows Actaeon during his transformation. He has the torso and arms of a man but the head and legs of a stag. The continuation of the story appears in the background, where Actaeon’s own dogs devour him.
title: Diana and Actaeon
